title: Baseball’s Oldest Team Is Also Its Most Old-School
text:
WASHINGTON—In an industry increasingly populated by young stars, young managers and young executives, the Washington Nationals have the oldest roster in baseball. They have two 35-year-olds in their starting rotation (Max Scherzer and Aníbal Sánchez), a 36-year-old on their bench (Howie Kendrick) and, at age 42, the sport’s oldest active player in their bullpen (Fernando Rodney).

That seems fitting, because the Nationals play a version of the game straight out of another era—and it has made them an unexpected championship contender.

The Nationals limped into Memorial Day weekend sitting at 19-31, shining a giant spotlight on the departure of superstar Bryce Harper and putting manager Dave Martinez in serious danger of losing his job. But since then they’ve been nearly unstoppable, surging into the first National League wild-card spot by playing about as well as any team in the majors.

They’ve accomplished this by specializing in so many of the elements of the game that seemingly had been lost to time. They steal bases. They bunt. They use the world “bullpen” only as a noun, not a verb. They’re showing that, contrary to the product on display at most stadiums around the country in 2019, maybe there’s more to baseball than home runs and strikeouts after all.

“I’ve seen how the game has evolved, and eventually the game is going to have to come back to what it was,” Martinez said.

Led by Max Scherzer, Washington’s starters have thrown more than 65% of the team’s innings, the most in baseball. Photo: raj mehta/Reuters

The Nationals are doing their part. They entered Sunday ranked third in sacrifice bunts since the beginning of their hot streak more than three months ago. They were fourth in steals, led by shortstop Trea Turner and outfielder Víctor Robles. They were last in strikeouts and seventh in walks, resulting in the NL’s best collective on-base percentage over that span. Their biggest slugger, quiet MVP candidate Anthony Rendon, strikes out in just 13.5% of his plate appearances. The league average is nearly 23%.

It has turned the Nationals into an offensive juggernaut that defies modern conventional wisdom. In a year where about 45% of all runs scored across the majors are via the home run—an all-time record—the Nationals are merely average at hitting the ball over the fence. They have enough power that it “puts the fear of God in them a little bit,” hitting coach Kevin Long said, but their output doesn’t rely on the long ball, either.

“A runner on first base is a rally in the playoffs,” 30-year-old outfielder Adam Eaton said. “The beauty of our team is that we can manufacture runs in different ways, not just with the home run.”

Washington Nationals relief pitcher Fernando Rodney, left, exits the bullpen cart. Photo: Nick Wass/Associated Press

Their pitching is even more of a throwback. The days of the starting rotation carrying a team have long passed by, gone the way of stirrups and wool flannel uniforms. Starters have handled less than 59% of the innings across the majors this season, the fewest in MLB history. “Bullpenning,” the once-radical strategy of eschewing a traditional starter in favor of a parade of relievers, is now a widespread practice.

Not with the Nationals. They lean on their starters not quite to the extent teams did decades ago, but certainly more than any other organization in 2019. Led by Scherzer, Stephen Strasburg and Patrick Corbin, Washington’s starters have thrown more than 65% of the team’s innings, the most in baseball.

They have the arms for that. Scherzer, a three-time Cy Young award winner, had thrown over 200 innings in six straight seasons heading into 2019, the only pitcher in baseball who could say that. Strasburg, despite a checkered injury past, has stayed healthy this year and should top 200 innings for the first time since 2014. Corbin has made at least 30 starts for the third consecutive year.

All told, the Nationals’ starters rank third in the majors in ERA, only behind the NL West-champion Los Angeles Dodgers and the Tampa Bay Rays.

“Every team would like their starters to go seven every time,” said Corbin, who left the Arizona Diamondbacks to sign a six-year, $140 million free-agent contract with Washington in December. “A big reason why I came here was to be a part of this rotation.”

Nationals shortstop Trea Turner steals second base. Photo: brad mills/Reuters

The Nationals entered the season shrouded in doubt, having missed the playoffs in 2018 after two straight division titles and then losing Harper, the face of the franchise, to the Philadelphia Phillies in free agency.

Inside the Nationals clubhouse, the players generally shy away from publicly discussing Harper. But they know what’s happening up Interstate 95: Though Harper has generally played well in his Philadelphia debut -- he entered Sunday with 31 homers and a career-high 102 RBIs -- the Phillies are on the fringes of the wild-card chase, while the Nationals continue to soar.

Other players have helped replace Harper’s production. Rendon, a free agent this winter, entered Sunday with a MLB-best 118 RBIs and leading the NL with a .331 batting average and 43 doubles. After his sensational rookie campaign as a teenager, 20-year-old Juan Soto has almost been as good as Harper ever was.

Harper loomed large early on, when the Nationals’ season was on the verge of collapse. Then they started winning—and nobody asked about Harper anymore.

“It was so bad and people had written us off that the pressure was off, and we were just like, ‘Let’s go play and see what we can do,’” closer Sean Doolittle said. “We started to play looser. We started to play better team baseball.”

The Nationals have yet to fix their glaring flaw: The bullpen, which entered Sunday with a whopping 5.92 ERA, the worst in baseball. Their 28 blown saves were tied for the most in the majors. In the playoffs, the Nationals could avoid their struggling relievers by using their extra starting pitchers out of the bullpen, a model the Houston Astros perfected in their run to a championship in 2017.

Victor Robles of the Washington Nationals lays down a sacrifice bunt. Photo: Rich Schultz/Getty Images

The Nationals have been in this position before, rolling into the playoffs brimming with optimism and lofty aspirations. They’ve reached the postseason four times since 2012, only to lose in the first round in each of those seasons.

This time, they insist they’ve already seen the benefits of fielding a veteran team: A younger group might not have recovered from their miserable start to the season, when their chances looked bleak.

“If you’re going over any large body of water, and you hit some rough waters early on, some of the young guys want to turn back and give in or give up,” Eaton said. “But if you have those guys on the boat who have made the trek before, they can say, ‘Hey, we’re going to have clear skies ahead.’”

Share Your Thoughts In an era dominated by home runs and strikeouts, can an old-school approach be effective in the postseason?

Write to Jared Diamond at jared.diamond@wsj.com
